Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Protection Division erred in dismissing the applicant's refugee claim based on religious persecution and forced sterilization risks
Governing_Law: Under Canadian immigration law, a valid refugee claim requires proof of persecution risk
Outcome: The Board erred by not addressing whether restrictions on the applicant's faith practice could amount to persecution. The decision is set aside for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Assumption that applicant would join a safe church in Fujian
Failure to assess specific situation or consider restrictions on faith practice
Basis_of_Claim: Risks related to China's One Child Policy
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Risk of persecution due to religious practice and forced sterilization
Application_Error: Failure to assess applicant's specific circumstances and potential persecution based on religious practice
Evidence_Ignored: Specific restrictions on applicant's ability to practice religion freely
Legal_Standard: Proof of risk of persecution under Canadian immigration law
Application_Factor: Membership in a particular social group
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside
Claim remitted for re-determination by a different panel
No costs awarded

Crimes.Crime_Name: Border document misrepresentation (if any material fact was concealed in visa application related to these events).
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the applicants conceal material facts in their visa applications related to their fear of persecution or risk of harm?
Crimes.Outcome: No evidence suggests visa application misrepresentation; focus was on procedural fairness and risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony regarding refugee claim, cooperation with authorities, gang retaliation fears
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96 and 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by Jamaican gang
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Truthful disclosure of material facts in visa applications
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicants claimed refugee status due to perceived risks from a Jamaican gang
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application allowed; case remanded for reconsideration by a different RPD panel

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess personalized risk under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Principal Applicant abducted, forced into robbery, witnessed murder, cooperated with police leading to gang member's death
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Details of abduction, cooperation with police, fear of Clansmen gang retaliation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to consider applicant’s role in gang member’s death
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed; matter returned for reconsideration by differently constituted RPD panel
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of RPD decision and re-hearing
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD unreasonably concluded risk was generalized based on economic status despite clear indicators of targeted retaliation

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Occurred during abduction and forced participation in criminal activity
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate (non-violent property crime but part of violent context)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk due to involvement in incident and cooperation with authorities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Witness testimony, police cooperation records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Positive
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code (theft under $5000)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to report a crime (attempted, due to fear and perceived police corruption)
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to notify claimants of key issue (generalized risk)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Principle of procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant feared reporting due to fear of gang retaliation and distrust in police
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of notice regarding 'generalized risk' as an issue
Crimes.Evidence_Used: History of abduction, witness to murder, cooperation with authorities
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored link between cooperation and personalized risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness and personalized risk assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to recognize personalized risk stemming from police cooperation

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of retaliation against applicant due to role in death
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct testimony, police reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and plausible account
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code (murder), IRPA s. 97(1)(b)

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Part of abduction and forced criminal participation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing threat due to past victimization and cooperation with authorities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical or police records (implied)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code (assault with a weapon), IRPA s. 97(1)(b)

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on fear of religious persecution
Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 72(1)
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to religious practice as a Christian in China
Legal_Framework: International refugee law, IRPA, Convention refugee definition
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision found unreasonable; remitted for re-determination by a different panel
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant seeking protection under IRPA
Targeted_Group: Unregistered Christians and house church members in Fujian province, China
State_Protection_Assessment: Board failed to adequately assess state protection in China
Risk_Factor: Destruction of house churches, inconsistent enforcement of registration rules
Credibility: Applicant's evidence on religious persecution was not reasonably assessed
Legal_Provision: IRPA definition of Convention refugee – well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of religion
State_Protection_Adequacy: Insufficient state protection for unregistered religious groups in China
Risk_Nature: Ongoing and systemic suppression of unregistered religious activities
Victim_Basis: Religious belief and practice outside state-sanctioned channels

Legal_Issue: Validity of RPD's decision after amendments
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credible evidence of persecution
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No material impact from undisclosed evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed
Judicial review dismissed

Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed

Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Legal_Standard: Perverse, capricious, or made without regard to evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 117(9)(d) excludes family members not examined during sponsor’s permanent residence process

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide key details (e.g., teacher’s name), whispering during hearings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of reasonable explanation
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; decision upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of negative credibility finding and recognition of refugee status
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution; credibility central to assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility undermined by false testimony; adequate state protection available in Hungary

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of misrepresentation on credibility and refugee claim
Crimes.Outcome: Refugee claim denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found lack of credibility due to narrative discrepancies and reliance on template stories
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Forms (PIFs), original and amended narratives, hearing conduct
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Definition of Convention refugee requiring well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Ethnic persecution as Roma in Hungary
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility and adequacy of state protection in Hungary
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of inaccurate PIFs due to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable basis for credibility and risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: N/A – court found evidence was properly assessed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; burden on applicant to prove risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Amendment of narratives and failure to explain initial inaccuracies
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of inaccurate PIFs and template-based narratives

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obstruction of Justice (alleged but not proven)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Allegation of procedural interference in refugee proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether delay in correcting false narratives constituted obstruction or procedural unfairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian law on obstruction of justice and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court examined timing of correction of narratives and role of counsel
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No finding of obstruction of justice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to prove breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent narratives affected perception but not deemed intentional obstruction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obstruction requires active interference with legal process
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Incompetence of prior counsel leading to false submissions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No obstruction found; procedural fairness upheld
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Opportunities given to applicants to clarify their story
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of natural justice
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants attributed inaccuracies to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, hearing transcripts, judicial review submissions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn RPD decision based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of IRPA

Crimes.Dispute_Type: False statements in sworn immigration forms
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether signing false PIFs constitutes perjury
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian law on perjury and immigration declarations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants signed declarations of truth despite later admitting falsehoods
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Presumption of truth in sworn declarations
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Contradiction between signed declarations and later admissions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Perjury involves knowingly making false statements under oath
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Language barriers and reliance on incompetent counsel
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Perjury inferred from attestation and subsequent retraction
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Signed PIFs, amended narratives, applicant testimony
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, criminal law on perjury
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed ignorance due to language and counsel issues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Sworn forms, affidavits, hearing records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Recognition of refugee status despite inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Oath requirements in immigration applications

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Duty of Fairness in Refugee Claims
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged procedural unfairness due to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD's process breached duty of fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of procedural fairness under Canadian administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD considered credibility and state protection with available evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies attributed to counsel, but applicants had chances to correct
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires opportunity to be heard
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness, reasonableness for findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Prior counsel submitted false narrative; applicants delayed correction
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Fair process upheld; applicants had multiple opportunities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Hearing transcripts, amendment requests, RPD questioning
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attributed errors to previous legal representation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Narratives, legal correspondence, hearing records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of RPD decision based on unfair process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Removal Orders
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 248 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to appear for removal interviews, lied about identity, and has a history of non-compliance
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, lied to authorities about identity
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ineffective past bonds and lack of credible bondsmen
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Detention review under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: History of non-compliance, proposed bondsmen details
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Proposed bondsmen lack strong ties to applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed not credible due to past lies and non-compliance
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Challenge to legality of continued detention
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Release from detention or alternative conditions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under section 248 of the Regulations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flight risk outweighs length of detention; alternatives insufficient
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention justification based on flight risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether continued detention is justified under immigration law
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not credible due to lying and missed interviews
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Past behavior, bondsmen relationship details
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 248 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Perceived risks upon return and inadequate bond consideration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Flight risk due to non-compliance and weak bond proposals
Crimes.Application_Error: None found; no reviewable error identified
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found evidence was properly considered
Crimes.Application_Factor: Proposed bondsmen not closely related, reducing reliability

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Justification of continued detention under immigration law
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility due to false statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Non-appearance at interviews, false identity claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 248 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Challenged detention order due to flight risk concerns
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: History of illegal stay and non-compliance
Crimes.Application_Factor: Bondsmen not closely related, raising doubts

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether continued detention is justified under IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not credible due to history of non-compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Past behavior with CBSA, bond proposal details
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 248 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Concerns over prolonged detention and rejected bonds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Flight risk due to past non-cooperation
Crimes.Application_Error: Allegation of inadequate consideration of alternatives
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Court found all relevant evidence was considered
Crimes.Application_Factor: Proposed bondsmen lacked close relationship to applicant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in interactions with immigration authorities

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or Misleading Information in Application for Government Benefits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mrs. Chhabu provided false or misleading information regarding her residency status to qualify for OAS and GIS benefits
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Review Tribunal's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Omission of second landing in 1987; travel history; property ownership in India
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate continuous residency
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inadequate explanation of absences and ties to India
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Residency determined by objective factors such as presence, ties, and absences; intention alone insufficient
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged false or misleading information in benefit application
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Unresolved due to unreasonable tribunal findings
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law and Old Age Security Act provisions on residency
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and remittal for reconsideration
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted to differently constituted Review Tribunal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of the Old Age Security Act relating to residency requirements
Crimes.Authority: Review Tribunal under the Old Age Security program

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residency Fraud under Old Age Security Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mrs. Chhabu was a resident of Canada since October 1986 under OAS rules
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted for redetermination due to unreasonable decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questionable due to extensive travel, Indian passport, property in India, and unexplained absences
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Old Age Security Act – residency definition and eligibility criteria
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation of residency through continued absences and foreign ties
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately address key evidence on residency
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective determination of residency based on facts and circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Impact of dementia, full context of absences, strength of ties to India
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Residency requires making Canada home and ordinarily living there, with temporary absences not exceeding one year
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of international travel, foreign assets, passport use
Crimes.Authority: Review Tribunal under the Old Age Security program
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Potential omission or misrepresentation in residency declaration forms

Crimes.Crime_Name: Acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations
Risk_Factor: alleged complicity in crimes by the Haitian National Police
Admission_or_Involvement: Kenny Merceron was a Haitian police officer during alleged abuses
Evidence_Credibility: insufficient evidence linking Merceron directly to crimes
Key_Evidence_Issue: mere membership does not equate to complicity without active participation
Credibility_Assessment: RPD erred by inferring complicity without evidence
Standard_of_Proof: reviewable error due to lack of sufficient evidence
Governing_Provision: Article 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Refugee Convention
Consequences_of_Action: refugee claim denied, judicial review granted, case remitted

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: exclusion from refugee protection based on alleged complicity
Outcome: application for judicial review allowed
Legal_Framework: Article 1F(a) and 1F(c) of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, case remitted for reconsideration
Risk_Factor: alleged complicity in systematic abuses by Haitian National Police
Credibility: knowledge of crimes insufficient to prove complicity
Risk_Nature: crimes against humanity as widespread or systematic attacks

Legal_Issue: Whether it was reasonable for the Minister's delegate to deny Mr. Fleet's request for relief from penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Fleet provided insufficient evidence to support his claim that CRA delays contributed to his failure to file; reliance on advisors was noted but not excused
Decision_Outcome: Denial of relief from penalties and interest was upheld as reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the taxpayer to demonstrate extenuating circumstances
Credibility_Factor: Mr. Fleet's claims were partially undermined by lack of supporting evidence
Legal_Rule: Section 220(3.1) allows waiver of penalties/interest if extenuating circumstances exist; taxpayers are accountable for actions of their advisors
Grounds_for_Claim: RRSP over-contribution due to erroneous advice from employer; request for penalty and interest relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Reliance on financial advisors, missed filing deadlines, failure to submit T1-OVP returns, alleged CRA processing delays
Defendant_Response: Mr. Fleet blamed CRA delays and relied on professional advice, but did not provide sufficient documentation
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, taxpayer testimony, administrative records
Remedy_Requested: Waiver or cancellation of penalties and interest on RRSP over-contributions
Outcome: Application dismissed; no costs awarded due to government error in advising Mr. Fleet
Authority: Minister's delegate, Tax Court of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant provided passport showing 1,097 days of physical presence in Canada within the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge applied two tests (Pourghasemi and Koo) instead of a single quantitative test
Evidence_Used: Passport records confirming days of physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge rejected persuasive evidence without justification
Credibility_Assessment: Improper credibility assessment based on 'quality of residence' rather than documented presence
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially rejected by citizenship judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative test for physical presence under section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by applying an incorrect legal test and failing to properly assess documentary evidence
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (initial decision), Federal Court (appellate review)

Violation_Type: Refusal of refugee status based on credibility and evidence assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Imputed political opinion, membership in a particular social group
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to imputed political opinion and social group membership
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of erroneous finding of fact or misinterpretation of evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board found applicant's claim implausible; preference given to documentary evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board assessed applicant's testimony as lacking credibility
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's negative refugee determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Plausibility of claim, risk of persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision supported by credible evidence; no misinterpretation or capricious error found
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Can the applicant's time for appeal be extended due to administrative errors causing delayed notification of the Registrar's decision?
Evidence_Assessment: Trademark agents' errors led to delayed notification; no fault on applicant's part
Decision_Outcome: Extension of time for appeal granted
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant demonstrated genuine intention to appeal and arguable case
Credibility_Factor: Applicant acted diligently; no delay attributable to them
Legal_Rule: Section 56(1) allows appeal within two months or further time as court may allow
Standard_of_Review: Balance of justice and equitable discretion
Grounds_for_Claim: Administrative error by trademark agents causing late notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Opposition originally rejected by Registrar; appeal not yet decided on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of notification, conduct of trademark agents, applicant’s intent
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of correspondence and timelines
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Outcome: Court allowed extension; applicant to pay respondent's costs and disbursements
Authority: Federal Court (implied from context of appeal under Trade-marks Act)

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent provided sufficient evidence of use of the trademark 'LE COLLEZIONI (TRADIZIONI) DI SUCCESSO' during the relevant three-year period
Governing_Law: Section 45 of the Trade-marks Act, Section 4 of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal to Federal Court under Section 56 of the Act
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits, labels, garment sample, advertisements, sales figures exceeding $18 million were assessed; found sufficient for suits, pants, shirts, and jackets but not other items
Decision_Outcome: Registrar's decision upheld; appeal dismissed with costs
Burden_of_Proof: On registrant to prove use of the trademark in Canada under Section 45
Credibility_Factor: Evidence provided by respondent was deemed credible and sufficient by the hearing officer
Legal_Rule: Section 45 requires proof of trademark use; 'use' is defined under Section 4
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard, unless new evidence materially affects findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant challenged the Registrar's decision on grounds of non-use of the trademark
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal dismissed; Registrar's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavits, product labels, physical garment sample, advertising materials, sales data
Defendant_Response: Respondent provided evidence of use including sales, advertising, and product samples
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (affidavits, labels), physical evidence (garment), financial records (sales data), promotional materials
Remedy_Requested: Cancellation of trademark registration for non-use
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; trademark registration maintained for certain goods
Legal_Provision: Section 45, Section 4, Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act

Crime_Name: Risk of Persecution or Harm upon Removal
Violation_Type: Failure to assess personalized risk as required by law
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil individual facing potential removal to Sri Lanka; Minister's Delegate concluded risk was generalized, not personalized
Procedural_Issue: Re-assessment process may have failed to properly apply the balance of probabilities test; risk of irreparable harm if removed prior to judicial review
Evidence_Used: Evidence indicating Tamils face unique dangers in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minister's Delegate dismissed specific risks to Tamils as generalized without sufficient justification
Decision_Outcome: Minister's Delegate found no more than generalized risk
Outcome: Stay of removal granted by the court
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of removal until resolution of judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Serious questions exist about the re-assessment; removal would render judicial review ineffective, constituting irreparable harm

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 876 days, failing to accumulate 1,095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the Citizenship Judge, governed by Federal Courts Rules
Evidence_Used: Record of absences and presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Citizenship application rejected
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the statutory physical presence test; no error in interpretation

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant provided letters, affidavits, and country condition documents post-RPD decision; Officer found them materially consistent with prior evidence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review sought; no oral hearing required
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Evidence not considered 'new' under IRPA s.113(a); materially consistent with prior submissions
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision was reasonable
Outcome: Application dismissed; judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Reconsideration based on new evidence in PRRA application
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Only new evidence affecting RPD outcomes is admissible under IRPA s.113(a)
Decision_Rationale: Submitted evidence did not establish new risks; consistent with prior evidence presented to RPD

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution from FARC in Colombia
Procedural_Issue: Lack of oral hearing despite credibility being central to decision
Evidence_Used: Officer acknowledged FARC's human rights violations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided by applicant to establish credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned applicant's credibility; credibility was central to the decision
Decision_Outcome: Pre-removal risk assessment application denied
Outcome: Decision overturned on judicial review
Relief_Sought: Procedural fairness in pre-removal risk assessment
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for procedural fairness; reasonableness for fact-driven determinations
Decision_Rationale: Oral hearing required when credibility is at issue; absence constituted procedural error
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer conducting pre-removal risk assessment

Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of adjudicator under the Canada Labour Code
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator's decision quashed due to bias and unreasonableness
Legal_Rule: Jurisdiction exists if employment is 'in or in connection with a federal work, undertaking or business'
Grounds_for_Claim: Unjust dismissal complaint by Indian Band employee
Outcome_on_Merits: Jurisdiction confirmed; merits not upheld due to procedural flaws
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of employment with Indian Band council, federal legislative authority under Indian Act
Defendant_Response: Indian Band challenged adjudicator's jurisdiction and decision
Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, jurisdiction affirmed

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Moderate risk due to familial relationship and immigration implications
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction record
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not in dispute
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law or criminal code provision on threats

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminality leading to inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to family member's criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 42 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 23 of the Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mother's permanent residency application affected by son's criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to family member inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction, age and dependency status of son
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Son's status as family member accepted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'family member' and admissibility under s. 72(1)(e)(i)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Dependent child under 22 at time of application remains a family member; inadmissibility bars principal applicant from meeting eligibility criteria
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex can re-litigate the invalidity of Merck's patent under licensee estoppel or is barred by res judicata
Decision_Outcome: Paragraph 14 of Apotex's defense struck out
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to challenge patent validity, but barred by prior final judgment
Legal_Rule: Res judicata bars re-litigation of issues already decided in a final judgment; issue estoppel applies if same question was decided, decision is final, and parties are the same
Grounds_for_Claim: Apotex's attempt to challenge patent validity based on licensee estoppel
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex cannot re-litigate patent validity due to res judicata
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior rulings by Federal Court of Appeal and other courts on patent validity
Legal_Framework: Principles of cause and issue estoppel
Defendant_Response: Apotex challenged the validity of Merck's patent in its defense
Remedy_Requested: Merck sought to strike paragraph 14 of Apotex's defense
Outcome: Merck's motion allowed with costs

Application_Facts: Officer considered medical accessibility and pending H&C application; daughter's medical needs; second H&C application not deemed imminent
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed Officer's reasoning on medical care accessibility and relevance of pending H&C application
Evidence_Used: CIC Health Management Branch advice on medical care in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision to deny deferral of removal was reasonable
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed
Decision_Rationale: Medical care available in Mexico; pending H&C application not imminent enough to warrant deferral

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of IAD's refusal to adjourn and dismiss the appeal
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Mental condition assessment sought but denied due to lateness and irrelevance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed by IAD; judicial review application dismissed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of remorse noted by IAD
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: IAD's decision found reasonable, no procedural breach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Requested adjournment to assess mental health
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical evaluation (proposed)
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Adjournment and allowance of appeal on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to serious criminality under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious Criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - Serious Criminality provisions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld on judicial review
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal to grant adjournment and dismissal of appeal
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk to public safety due to criminal record
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's claims regarding disability not accepted due to late submission
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section on serious criminality leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Domestic criminal conduct posing societal risk

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed threats from FARC in Colombia and lack of safe internal flight alternative (IFA) in Pereira; Board found FARC threat concentrated elsewhere and insufficient evidence that applicant would be targeted in Pereira
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining an IFA existed
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence, applicant's testimony, evidence on FARC activities and conditions in Pereira
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof that FARC could locate or target the applicant in Pereira; lack of evidence of adverse conditions in Pereira
Decision_Outcome: Board determined IFA in Pereira was available
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Internal Flight Alternative test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution in IFA location; (2) reasonable conditions for seeking refuge
Decision_Rationale: Threat from FARC was not established in Pereira; conditions in Pereira did not rise to level of unreasonableness; psychological effects alone did not undermine safety
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for over 692 days within the four-year period preceding the application; had stronger connections to the Middle East than to Canada
Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies in reported absences indicating potential misrepresentation
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, applicant's reported travel, ties to Canada vs. Middle East
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent reporting of absences, lack of documentation supporting physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined due to discrepancies in absence reports
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Applicant did not meet residency requirements
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication permitted in the future upon meeting requirements
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Frequent and prolonged absences from Canada, insufficient residential ties, and credibility concerns
